p: Sustainable forestry activities aimed at maintaining or enhancing carbon (C) stocks in both forest ecosystems and wood products, including product substitution benefits, can make a significant contribution to reducing greenhouse gases (GHG) emissions [ 43, 45]. To date, the U.S. remains legally committed to reducing net GHG emissions by 26â€“28% by 2025 compared with 2005 levels [ 54]. Furthermore the U.S. Mid-Century Strategy set ambitious goals of an economy-wide reduction of GHG emissions of at least 80% below 2005 levels by 2050 [ 54]. Achieving these goals requires a diverse range of mitigation activities across all economic sectors, including substantial contributions from forests and wood products. Carbon sequestration by U.S. forests currently offsets approximately 15% of annual C emissions from fossil fuels in the U.S. [ 58] and studies have indicated significant potential to increase this service [ 37, 41], as well as reduce or delay the expected decline in the forest C sink [ 58].
